  20. Walkability – Understanding health factors like active transportation, bike paths and walking paths in a neighborhood.

Reporting/News

  1. Hurricane Andrew – Comparing geographically which homes fared better from Hurricane Andrew’s destruction because of changes in building code from Steve Doig’s piece that earned him a Pulitzer Prize.

  2. North Korea – Mapping how far North Korea’s missile projectiles threaten other nations – previously a buffer – now corrected. (North Korea Missile Extent)

  3. GeoJournalism – Assisting journalisms dive into a world of data visualization using geographic data. (GeoJournalism)

  4. Geotagged Tweets – Spreading the word to make world headlines from local Missouri and eventually the whole world. (CartoDB Geotagged Tweets)

  5. Mapping Conflict – Putting any crisis, destruction or terror attack on the map.

  6. Google News Lab – Storytelling around the globe with Google Maps and Fusion Tables (Google News Lab)

  7. Super GIS – Estimating the number of protestors at a Hong Kong rally by obtaining the average density of the crowd and estimating the number of protesters through aerial photo interpretation. (Protestor Estimate – Super GIS)

  8. Highway Accidents – Reporting the location of highway accidents on a map

  9. Demographics Research – Delving into census information for a deep research news story

  10. Ballot Counts – Depicting the spatial Distribution of states, districts, and parties that won an election

  11. The Financial Times – Utilizing tools like Mapbox to create elegant basemaps with all the right details. (Financial Times – Mapbox Studio Classic)

Society Applications – Built & Environment

  1. Thematic Mapping – Thematic mapping poverty with equal-intervals, quantiles, natural breaks and unique schemes. (“Making Maps Third Edition by John Krygier”)

  2. Socio-Economic Data and Application Center (SEDAC) – Serving socioeconomic and Earth science data as an information gateway between the Earth and social sciences focuses on human interactions in the environment. (SEDAC)

  3. World Languages – Mapping the world’s languages through social media and micro-blogging platforms. (World Languages)

  4. Poverty – Sizing up poverty with the FAO GeoNetwork socio-economic indicators. (FAO GeoNetwork)

  5. Hunting Zones – Tracing out hunting zones for cultures around the world.

  6. Citizen Engagement – Empowering populations who have little voice in the public arena to change geographic involvement and awareness on a local level. (Ushahidi Public Participation Geographic Information Systems (PPGIS))

  7. Needs of Services – Allocating the proper needs and inclusion of marginalized populations.

  8. Census – Utilizing decennial TIGER data to support and improve selected demographic and economic studies.

  9. World Religions – Mapping the intricate details of religions internationally.

  10. Space-time GIS – Comparing scientific practice in the US and in China (Space-Time GIS – Michael F. Goodchild)

  11. Center of Population – Centering in on population drift watching its shift in dasymetric mapping. (Population Drift – Joseph Kerski)

  12. Earthworks – Downloading data from Stanford including labor supply, sex ratio and society data. (Earthworks)

  13. Gender Inequality – Showing the history of how women are working in the GIS field. (Gender Inequality)

  14. Demography – Projecting populations worldwide with a dot density style map.

  15. Chart Symbology – Taking advantage of pie charts, line graphs and bar charts to display socio-economic data by area.

  16. Indigenous People – Keeping record of traditional land use of indigenous people.

  17. Public Transportation Availability – Reviewing public transit availability in societies.

  18. Population Disaggregation – Estimating per-building population through disaggregation of census blocks

  19. Distance Decay – Observing distance-decay between locations of ethnic groups- the further apart they are, the less likely it is that they will interact very much.

  20. Refugee Camps – Capturing the movement patterns of refugees through time. (Refugee Patterns)

  21. Traditional Knowledge – Preserving cultural beliefs and its associated location in a spatial database.

  22. Tapestry Segmentation – Dividing U.S. residential areas into 67 distinctive segments based on their socioeconomic and demographic composition—then further classifies the segments into LifeMode and Urbanization Groups. (Tapestry Segmentation)

  23. Migrant Rescue – Improving Humane operations and rescuing migrants through the deployment of emergency water stations on routes known to be used by migrants coming north through our desert. (Migrant Rescue)

  24. Prism Maps – Drawing each boundary object as a raised prism, where the height of the prism is relative to the associated data value. (Golden Software Map Viewer)

  25. Group Decision Making – Mediating interests and getting valued-concerns in community and society through PGIS.

  26. Maori Tribe – Recording, organizing, and making available information of traditional values from Maori elders. (Maori Tribe Elders)

  27. Human Mobility – Measuring of human mobility using mobile phone records enhanced with GIS data.

  28. Graffiti – Studying clusters of graffiti with other factors such as proximity to city constructs such as crossing guards, phone boxes and electricity boxes.

  29. Storytelling with Maps – Harnessing the power of story maps such as understanding the gap between minimum wage and high income earners. (Income Earning in Maps)

  30. Illiteracy in Myanmar – Building literacy in Myanmar and evaluating literacy programs in a GIS database with indicators such as budgeted funds, dropout levels and available training.

  31. Gender Studies – Exploring how transportation infrastructure support mobility access to basic services vital to achieving poverty reduction, gender equality, and sustainable development objectives in Ghana. (Gender Inequality)

  32. Child Abuse – Allocating family service facilities to sites where child abuse is more prevalent.

Soils

  1. Soil Types – Modelling soil types through Jenny’s model involving climate, organisms, topography, material and time.

  2. Soil Grid – Helping agriculture decision-making with ISRIC’s 1km scale soil property and class maps of the world. (SoilsGrid)

  3. Texture Classification – Digging up the dirt on soil texture through the USDA soil texture classification

  4. Soil Moisture – Estimating soil moisture from space with the SMAP and SMOS satellites

  5. Soil Survey Geographic Database (SSURGO) – Making sense of soil parameters like conductivity in the United States. (USDA SSURGO Database)

  6. Water Retention Capacity – Determining water retention capacity for different type of soils and topographic characteristics.

  7. Erosion Reduction Strategy – Identifying erosion hot spots through topography, soil and land-use characteristics. (Erosion and Sediment Control)

  8. Slope Parameters – Developing slope profiles such as convex and concave using 3D profile graphs.

  9. Soil Loss Equation – Measuring the average annual soil loss caused by rainfall and associated overland flow as defined by the United States Department of Agriculture.

  10. Lead Concentration in Soils – Collecting soil samples and mapping the lead geochemical landscape. (Mapping Lead Concentrations)

  11. LS Factor – Calculating slope length (LS) factor as part of the Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE) based on slope and specific catchment area.

  12. Angle of Repose – Computing the steepest angle (depending on the material) of a surface at which loose material such as soil will remain in place rather than sliding or crumbling.

  13. Salinity – Inspecting salinity with electromagnetic surveys to find the electrical conductivity in soils and interpolating the results to find unknowns.

  14. Peaks and Summits – Detecting peaks and summits on a landscape to help model salinity with elevation such as depression areas have higher salinity. (Landserf)

  15. Vegetation Erosion – Finding the dominant vegetation types dependent on aspect and enhancing erosion modelling using aspect and vegetation to see how slopes will erode over time along with precipitation, temperature and growing periods.

  16. Stereoscopy Tools – Creating stereo pairs from two aerial photographs with anaglyph and virtual-z mode. (PurVIEW)

  17. Normalized Difference Soil Index (NDSI) – Gauging soil water content from space using shortwave infrared, near infrared wavelength and NDSI.

Sports & Recreation

  1. Strava Heat Map – Heating up the road with over 375 billion data points showing you exactly which routes other cyclists are taking. (Strava Bicycle Routes)

  2. Fitbit – Plugging in your Fitbit to map your runs.

  3. Tennis Analytics – Dominating your tennis opponent with in-depth spatial analytics. (Tennis Analytics)

  4. Ski Hill – Creating vicious triple black diamond ski runs using steepest path.

  5. Hiking Trail – Incorporating factors in trail development like gentle slopes for an accumulated least cost path.

  6. Optimal Road Trip – Planning a road trip of the century across the United States using the shortest route for all major landmarks.

  7. Golf Course Water Systems – Planning a golf course’s underground water system and sprinkler system in 3D.

  8. Rollercoaster – Creating realistic a fly-through from interpolated paths using 3D animation capability in ArcGIS Pro. (Rollercoaster Animation)

  9. Heli-skiing – Assessing the impacts of heli-skiing on mountain animal behavior using GPS trackers and frequently skiing areas.

  10. Stadium Security – Getting the big picture by giving police and emergency responders to track activities on a web-based geospatial platform.

  11. Mountaineering – Climbing steep slopes in Google Street View.

  12. Surf Breaks – Sizing up wave heights from satellite radar altimeters in orbit. (GlobWave Project)

  13. Marathon Routing – Planning the route of a marathon using elevation and base maps.

  14. 3D Ski Maps – Touring a mountain virtually in realistic 3D virtual tours. (3D Ski Maps in Golden Software)

  15. Football Stadiums – Turn maps into straight line journeys with FME’s ShortestPathFinder transformer. (Football Stadiums Journeys)

  16. Google Earth Elevation Transect – Pulling out steep slopes using the elevation transect tool in Google Earth for any given cycling and jogging route.

  17. Geocaching – Hunting for treasures and even survey monuments through geocaching.

  18. Swisstopo – Sculpting beautiful topography maps in 3D. (SwissTopo)

  19. Fishing Maps – Creating 3D bathymetric maps in real-time with Sonar (Navionics)

  20. Ride Sharing – Providing optimal and dynamic ride sharing in urban areas.

  21. Mapbox Outdoors – Powering your fitness and outdoor applications with terrain maps that highlight thousands of biking, hiking and running trails as well as ascents through topography lines. (Mapbox Outdoors)

  22. Sports Stadiums – Viewing complex geometries like sports stadiums in 3D. (Vizitown QGIS 3D Plugin)

Surveying/Geodesy

  1. Coordinate Calculator – Converting coordinate conversion tool of choice for GIS. (Geography Calculator – Global Mapper)

  2. Fibre Optic Cable Design – Extracting LiDAR ground points to assist in fibre optic cable design at water crossings.

  3. Tissot Circles – Characterizing distortion from map projections (Indicatrix Mapper QGIS Plugin)

  4. Global Positioning Systems – Locating the position of anything and anywhere on Earth.

  5. Ordnance Survey – Drafting out maps as one of the largest producers of maps in the World. (Ordnance Survey)

  6. Equator Bulge – Measuring the bulge of Earth at the equator

  7. Bearings – Importing bearings and distances from a survey for parcel mapping and transcribing it on a map.

  8. Triangulation – Using trigonometry to measure the angles in a triangle formed by three survey control points

  9. Shuttle Radar Topographic Mission (SRTM) – Obtaining a global digital elevation model from inSAR. (SRTM)

  10. Geodetic National Adjustment – Adjusting datum positions with the Geodetic National Adjustment.

Telecommunications

  1. Radio-Wave Propagation – Estimating the propagation of radio-waves for network with complex reflections and diffraction and line-of-sight.

  2. Locating Cell Towers – Locating cell tower placements in urban areas using 3D building structures.

  3. Network Management – Managing a network of telecommunication cables and towers in a network data set.

  4. Fresnel Zones – Finding the region of space between wireless transmitter and receiver where obstructions cause interference to the signal.

  5. Antenna Height Optimization – Optimizing antenna height using GIS 3D modelling.

  6. Operations Support Systems (OSS) – Ensuring that network functions properly including outages, billing, and testing through GIS shared services.

  7. Submarine Cable – Sketching out submarine cables that stretch across oceans. (Submarine Cable Map)

  8. Network Signal Interpolation – Clustering geographically high and low network signals and interpolating results in cellular signal maps

  9. Cellular Coverage Analysis – Maximizing cellular coverage using tower height by using interference analysis including viewshed and line-of-sight.

  10. Frequency Management – Regulating radio spectrum to evaluate frequency interactions when approving applications using use terrain, environment, and building data. (Spectrum Regulation)

  11. Fibre Optic Cable – Planning fibre optic cable infrastructure through network views showing capacity, equipment and customer demographics.

  12. Market Segmentation – Segmenting customers geographically and forecast the demand for services where growth is likely to occur.

  13. Operations – Investigating interruptions in service and managing repair and maintenance work with the Autodesk Topobase infrastructure model. (LIWEST and AutoCAD 3D)

  14. Signal Expansion – Planning expansion by better understanding signal strengths in three dimensional buildings – or mapping your home Wi-Fi signal in 2D.

Tourism

  1. Personality Atlas – Assigning personality stereotypes to countries around the world based on a sample size of global population’s perspectives. (Personality Atlas)

  2. Tourist Map – Plotting out landmarks in tourist maps.

  3. Sunrise and Sunset – Finding the perfect sunrise and sunset during at any given location. (SunCalc)

  4. Subway Map – Simplifying maps for the reader to better understand such as the lines of a subway map in high contrasting colors. (Cartographer Toolkit – Gretchen Peterson)

  5. Linear Referencing – Using linear referencing along shorelines to track volumes of organic debris.

  6. Off-Beaten Tracks – Finding the off-beaten track for backpackers and marking its position with 3 words. (Off-Beaten Track Location – What3Words)

  7. Safe Travel – Advising travelers where unsafe location are on a map.

  8. Tourism Dollars – Tracking the exports of purchased goods and services using desire lines.

  9. Sustainable Tourism Planning – Identifying conflicting interests from tourism and solving issues by examining suitable locations for proposed developments.

  10. Hotel Search – Searching geographically for five star hotels using a circle radius.

  11. Horizon Blockage – Calculating the horizon blocking line in all directions from a given observation point with gvSIG’s Horizon Blockage.

  12. Travel Mode Detection – Detecting travel mode (walk, car, bus, subway and commuter rail) from a multi-modal transportation network using GIS and GPS in New York City.

  13. Finding Islands – Using satellite to find uninhabited islands around the world – Landsat found Landsat Island near the coast of Canada.

  14. Time Zones – Representing time zones around the world.

  15. Eco-Tourism Site Selection – Gauging environmental impacts for sustainable eco-tourism sites.

  16. Virtual Travel – Seeing your destination before physically being there. (Google Earth Street View)

  17. Geo-tagging – Discover places with 360 panoramic camera views. (Mapillary)

  18. Highway Planning – Constructing viewpoints with multiple layers like ecology, topography and cultural features for a three-dimensional visual highway.

  19. Virtual Arctic – Exploring the Arctic in Google Street View without getting out of your chair.

  20. 3D Synthetic Scene – Overlaying synthetic scenes over real scene. (Manifold)

  21. Life Travels – Accompanying travellers in their life travels in map-form. (Where in the World is Andrew?)

  22. Yellowstone – Putting all the pieces together in a GIS database at Yellowstone National Park including its geologic past, geyser recharge and seismic activity.

  23. Trip Planning – Adventuring around for your next road trip with pit stops and offbeat using suggested sites.

  24. Observer Points – Calculating visibility through multiple observer points.

  25. Historic Street View – Time-travelling in the past to see just how much a location has changed over time with historic street view.

Transmission

  1. Corridor Analyst – Identifying possible corridors and preferred transmission routes using Least Cost Path engineering, environment and combined routing algorithms. (Trimble Corridor Analyst)

  2. Transmission Line Monitoring – Monitoring overhead transmission towers with active and passive satellite data.

  3. Viewshed – Understanding the impacts of how a transmission line would look using viewsheds.

  4. Right-of-way – Buffering proposed transmission lines which will be areas cleared for the transmission line.

  5. Transmission Line Design – Considering slope, soils and land use for factoring into transmission line design.

  6. Tree Encroachment – Reducing risk of falling trees with LiDAR in search for dead and dying trees near utility lines.

  7. Public Consultation – Visualizing the transmission line with towers during public using 2D and 3D environments.

  8. Line Vision – Synchronizing 2D viewing in 3D environments with viewports. (gvSIG 3D Plugin)

  9. 3D Geometry – Sketching up custom 3D transmission towers and lines for import into ArcScene. (Google SketchUp and COLLADA)

  10. Line Profile – Utilizing slope profiles to generate terrain profiles with Manifold GIS.

  11. Environmental Monitoring – Referencing environmentally sensitive sites along a linear transmission and reporting conflicting points.

  12. Map Automation – Generating maps automatically from tiles along a transmission corridor with ArcGIS Data Driven Pages or QGIS Atlas.

Transportation

  1. Travelling Salesman – Constructing efficient journeys that visit any number of points on a network in no particular order. (Travelling Salesman)

  2. Hadoop – Leveraging the Hadoop framework for millions of data points with big data spatial analytics. (Hadoop Framework)

  3. Deadliest Roads – Pinpointing the safest and deadliest roads on the planet with the Roads Kills Map. Spoiler: Dominican Republic has the most dangerous roads. (Roads Kill Map)

  4. Multimodal – Getting cars off the road for multi-modal options by studying cycling paths and walkability.

  5. Turn Restrictions – Adding restrictions to U-turns in a network dataset. (TNT Network Analysis)

  6. Parking Demand – Estimating parking demand and its fit with parking capacity with Python. (PARKFIT)

  7. A/B Testing – Making real-world choices sending cars to various routes for the fastest deliveries. (Spatial A/B Testing)

  8. Closest Facility – Solving the cost of traveling between incidents and facilities for which are nearest to one other.

  9. Infrastructure Damage – Reporting damaged infrastructure in a browser web mapping system.

  10. Motor Vehicle Collisions – Correlating motor vehicle collisions with spatial attributes such as speed limits, guardrails and on-street parking.

  11. Intersection Analysis – Improving intersection safety through crash and road safety analysis with the MapWindow Safety Software Plugin.

  12. Intelligent Transportation System (ITS) – Feeding data from GPS units, video cameras, and road monitoring units to advance efficiency and safety of transportation systems.

  13. Shortest Path – Generating the shortest, fastest, or least-costly route between any number of origins and any number of destinations, with any number of intermediate points. (Shortest Path)

  14. Vessel Tracking – Plotting automatic identification system (AIS) points on a map in real-time.

  15. Network Travel Costs – Determining travel costs from each origin to all destinations

  16. Road Asset Management – Using ground survey data showing assets on a roadway in Manifold GIS.

  17. UPS Parcel Delivery – Seeing every driver in near-real time to study safety and find shorter routes – saving time, tire tread, and costs.

  18. Floating Car Systems – Displaying taxi fleet in one hour. (Floating Car Systems – Anita Graser)

  19. Logistics Management – Planning, implementing, and controlling the efficient effective flow and storage of goods and services from a point of origin to point of consumption.

  20. Street Repair – Inventorying and reporting repairs on streets.

  21. Road Assessment – Taking measure of pavement through aerial and mobile LiDAR.

  22. Trip Generation/Production – Estimating the number of trips that are produced or originate in each zone of a study area. (TransCAD Trip Generation and Production)

  23. Railways – Tying railways together with CartoDB’s railways map – from cargo to passenger trains. (Railroads – A Staple for Growth)

  24. Service Areas – Identifying service areas from a fixed points along a network route to show response coverage for emergency vehicles.

  25. OD Cost Matrix – Improving coordination amongst transportation providers when given multiple origins and multiple destinations.

  26. Paratransit – Accessing rides through address entry and buffering points to find nearest routes.

  27. World Traffic – Helping drivers get to destinations efficiently with traffic conditions around the world. (World Traffic Map)

  28. Transportation Master Plan – Planning future highways and roads by looking at growth of communities and traffic demand.

  29. Airline Planning – Navigating to safer airspace by including nearby land use to runway lighting systems.

  30. Routing Workers – Optimizing routes by seeing overlap which saves fuel costs.

  31. Traffic Ways – Seeing the world as only traffic ways. (Traffic Ways)

  32. Carpooling – Adding carpool lots by analyzing the number of incoming trips in a city.

  33. Bus Route – Designing transit routes with cost and demographic impacts. (TransMix Transit Planning)

  34. Active Transportation Planning – Leveraging the public with Participatory Geographic Information Systems and active transportation

  35. Conflation – Conflating two road datasets with OpenJump Vivid extension “Road Mapper” or Spatial Adjustment in ArcGIS.

  36. Infrastructure Life Cycle – Reiterating the process of planning, designing, constructing, operating, and maintaining a transportation system.

  37. Inter-modal Transportation – Compiling two different modes of transportation (such as rail and truck) to move goods or passengers.

  38. Rails-to-Trails Conservancy – Converting unused railway into a paved multi-use paths. (Rails-to-Trails)

  39. Traffic Congestion – Alleviating traffic congestion by making the best possible use of the existing transportation network and gathering data to improve decisions for modifying the network.

  40. Sidewalk Inventory – Storing sidewalk data in a database with attributes like width, surface type and clearing priority.

  41. Transit Ridership – Collecting statistics on how many passengers ride transit in a given neighborhood.

  42. National Bridge Inventory – Making a repository of bridges in a national-wide database.

  43. UPS Telematics – Monitor performance and safety of package cars Safety including seatbelt usage, speed and whether or not a door was shut.

  44. Urban Traffic Air Pollution – Recording urban traffic air pollution and quality trough 3D visualization in planar and non-planar views.

  45. Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis – Selecting highway route using multiple criteria. (Multi-criteria Decision Analysis QGIS Plugin)

  46. Walkability – Mapping out hot spots and cold spots with walkability and kernel density.

  47. Bike Sharing – Optimizing locations bike-sharing programs stations.

Utilities

  1. Billing Systems – Updating and correcting billing system for the cost of street and security lighting. (Spatial Billing Systems)

  2. Network Management – Visualizing complex spatial webs of utility networks as the foundation to manage the lifecycle of network assets for utilities. (GE Smallworld)

  3. Emergency Repairs – Flagging potential emergencies with weather forecasts, staging support where needed and logistics for the movement of people.

  4. Underground Utilities – Penetrating the ground with radar for precise locations of underground gas, water, electrical and telephone utilities.

  5. Pole Inventory – Pinning down with GPS accuracy utility poles.

  6. Power Distribution – Figuring out where in a distribution line could take down an entire network.

  7. Vegetation Encroachment – Overlaying LiDAR data with transmission to see where and how much vegetation is encroaching

  8. Subsurface 3D Utility Model – Viewing underground utilities in 3D.

  9. Lifecycle Management – Updating life cycle status of utility information as existing or proposed in GE SmallWorld

  10. Permafrost – Assessing the impacts of permafrost freezing and thawing on utility lines.

  11. Utility Pole Replacement – Obtaining all the information when replacing utility poles and other business operations (Asset ID, construction date, overhead/underground conductor and conductors it supports with number of wire and cable segments

  12. Power Outages – Helping customers keep the lights on with assets and attributes such as poles and transformers in AutoCAD Map 3D.

  13. Cost Path – Laying out a gas pipeline from one location to another location with a CAD schematic in AutoCAD 3D.

  14. Energy Usage – Mapping trends of electricity usage that are metered to a network.

  15. Smart Grids – Determining optimal locations for smart grid and real-time analytic components.

  16. Infrastructure Design – Planning network infrastructure, build, operations and maintenance with Smallworld Core.

  17. Energy Demand Estimation – Combining building volume, number of floors and other characteristics to predict the energy demand for heating and cooling using 3D city models in Germany. (Energy Demand Estimates)

  18. Schematics – Representing a complex utilities network in a simple schematics diagram with ArcGIS Schematics.

  19. Street View Measure – Examining utility operations in street view and measuring distances (MM Plugin in ArcGIS)

  20. Line Extension Easements – Creating electrical line extension easements (legal rights of access) in GE SmallWorld Electric Office Geospatial Asset Management

  21. Cloud Computing – Building and sharing maps in the cloud for common operating and faster decision-making. (GIS Cloud)

Volunteer GIS and Open Technology

  1. GIS Corps – Volunteering in GIS projects such as bridging the divide between the world’s insurance markets and the most vulnerable, low-income people. (GIS Corps)

  2. National Geographic Society – Preserving and protecting our planet as a global non-profit organization funding hundreds of projects each year. (National Geographic Society)

  3. Urban and Regional Information Systems Association (URISA) – Solving challenges in local and national governments through GIS and other information technologies. (URISA)

  4. Wikimapia – Describing the world in online, editable maps and mashups with free data available for you to experiment with and create unique applications. (Wikimapia)

  5. OpenStreetMap – Establishing open information as a free, editable map through volunteered input. (Founder Steve Coast)

  6. Open Geospatial Consortium – Making quality open standards for the global geospatial community. (Open Geospatial Consortium)

  7. USGS Earth Explorer – Opening up satellite data to the world for free. (USGS Earth Explorer)

  8. NASA World Wind – Monitoring weather patterns, visualize cities and terrain, track the movement of planes, vehicles and ships, analyze geospatial data, and educate people about the Earth with the cross-platform, Java-based NASA World Wind. (NASA World Wind)

  9. Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo) – Supporting the collaborative development of open source geospatial software, and promoting its widespread use. (OSGeo)

  10. ArcGIS Open Data – Exploring tens of thousands of data sets around the world from thousands of organizations around the world. (ArcGIS Open Data)

  11. Real-Time Collaboration – Collaborating in OpenStreetMap with multiple user entries. (Real-time Collaboration)

  12. Natural Earth – Producing public domain data with beautiful cartography layers.

  13. Volunteered Geographic Information (VGI) – Harnessing tools to create, assemble, and disseminate geographic data provided voluntarily by individuals (Citizens as Sensors – Goodchild, 2007)

  14. QGIS – Pioneering the #1 option for open GIS software. (QGIS Founder – Gary Sherman)

Weather

  1. Real-time Lightning – Capturing real-time lightning strikes in a map with monitoring stations located around the world. (Real-time Lightning)

  2. Global Wind Vectors – Displaying gusting winds with vectors as directions. (Global Wind – Null School)

  3. Albedo – Measuring albedo for Earth’s heat budget using surface reflectance satellite data – bright areas reflect more than dark areas.

  4. Solar Irradiance – Harnessing the power of solar energy with the Global Horizontal Solar Irradiance. (Global Horizontal Irradiance)

  5. Night-Day Boundary – Illustrating which parts of the Earth that people are fast asleep and are wide awake with the night-day boundary map. (Night-Day Boundary)

  6. Rainfall – Illustrating rainfall in NOAA’s National Weather Service web map. (Spatial Rainfall)

  7. NASA Ocean Color – Downloading chlorophyll-a concentrations and sea surfaces temperature data sets for studying the increasing risk from ocean acidification and hypoxia. (NASA Ocean Color)

  8. Historical Weather – Discerning weather patterns by studying old weather. (Old Weather)

  9. Temperature – Mapping out temperature with multi-dimensional NetCDF which includes dimensions of latitude, longitude, altitude, and time. (NASA Temperature NetCDF)

  10. Snowfall – Knowing how much snowfall occurred where. (NOAA Snowfall Data)

  11. Azimuth – Calculating solar elevation, solar azimuth, and sun hours in the sky for each location (R.Sun – GRASS GIS)

  12. Weather Anomalies – Tracking weather events in a spatial database such as snow in the Sahara desert or southern Algeria.

  13. 3D Snow Depths – Plotting out 3D snow depths at ski resorts using Golden Software. (Snow Depth Map)

  14. Pacific Ocean Blob – Mapping the extent of “The Blob” – an anomalous body having sea surface temperature much above the normal.

  15. 3D Atmospheric Data – Visualizing layers of the atmospheric features as a vertical profile.

  16. Ocean Surface Current Analysis Real-Time (OSCAR) – Delivering near real-time global ocean surface currents. (OSCAR Data)

  17. Weather Warnings – Feeding out live warnings with physical locations from National Weather Service. (Weather Warnings)

  18. Historical Precipitation – Observing historical precipitation from ground stations and radar in NetCDF with MapWindow Meteobase.

  19. Cirrus Clouds – Detecting cirrus cloud with Landsat’s Cirrus band.

  20. Hovmoller Diagrams – Plotting meteorological data with latitude and longitude as axis. (Hovmoller Diagrams – ILWIS)

  21. Doppler Radar – Predicting rainfall using Doppler Radar.

  22. Sky View Factor – Considering the visible sky and topographic influences to estimate radiation balances, temperature and evapotranspiration.

  23. Weather Stations – Obtaining the latitude and longitude positions of weather stations around the world.

item.title: Utils
item.description:
Note: this page is only a draft, but this project is hosted on a public repository where anyone can contribute. Learn how to contribute in less than a minute.

Utils

Here you will find a list of generic tools and resources that we found useful to help you during your developments.

Table of contents

  • Tools
    • Format converters
  • Front end libraries
  • Other
  • Localized resources
    • Spanish

Tools

Format converters

  • Convert a CSV to GeoJSON

  • Convert Esri JSON to GeoJSON

  • Dump vector tiles to GeoJSON

  • Terraformer: JavaScript (Front and back) - A geographic toolkit for dealing with geometry, geography, formats, and building geo databases

  • public-transit-tools: GTFS

Front end libraries

  • LabelGun: reducing label clutter across mapping libraries

Other

  • A tool to help test CORS requests
  • Postman
  • A swiss army knife for your ArcGIS Online and Portal for ArcGIS accounts
  • Chrome extensions

Localized resources

Spanish

  • Terraformer Toolkit
item.content:encoded:
Note: this page is only a draft, but this project is hosted on a public repository where anyone can contribute. Learn how to contribute in less than a minute.

Utils

Here you will find a list of generic tools and resources that we found useful to help you during your developments.

Table of contents

  • Tools
    • Format converters
  • Front end libraries
  • Other
  • Localized resources
    • Spanish

Tools

Format converters

  • Convert a CSV to GeoJSON

  • Convert Esri JSON to GeoJSON

  • Dump vector tiles to GeoJSON

  • Terraformer: JavaScript (Front and back) - A geographic toolkit for dealing with geometry, geography, formats, and building geo databases

  • public-transit-tools: GTFS

Front end libraries

  • LabelGun: reducing label clutter across mapping libraries

Other

  • A tool to help test CORS requests
  • Postman
  • A swiss army knife for your ArcGIS Online and Portal for ArcGIS accounts
  • Chrome extensions

Localized resources

Spanish

  • Terraformer Toolkit
